abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for this project are as
            follows: The project outcome is satisfactory, project
            sustainability is likely, the institutional development
            impact is substantial, Bank performance overall is highly
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance is overall
            satisfactory. This project was one of the first efforts by
            the Bank to simultaneously address reintegration and
            rehabilitation issues. The division of labor between the
            implementing agencies worked well. Originally, these two
            functions were housed in the same unit, but it was decided
            to manage the demobilization and reintegration function as a
            separate unit to ensure a greater impact. Keeping these
            functions separate also makes sense from a service delivery
            perspective. Consider separating disarmament and
            demobilization activities(DD) from the reintegration (R)
            program.  Be realistic about how much community
            participation is feasible during the early phase of a
            post-conflict situation. The Bank played an important role
            in creating the Multi-Donor Trust Fund, which made it
            feasible to rapidly scale up the response in accordance with
            the higher than expected number of ex-combatants seeking
            reintegration services. Independent financial management and
            procurement unit may increase effectiveness of post-conflict
            investments. Conduct capacity assessment of nongovernmental
            organization sector and plan up-front capacity-building
            program during design phase. In the context of the economic
            causes of conflicts, consider establishing investment
            targets. Project design should be structured around few
            easy-to-monitor key performance indicators, based on
            relatively simple base line studies. When appropriate
            address DDR issues at the regional level. In post-conflict
            situations, it is difficult to envisage requirements and
            thereby plan for bulk procurement. There should be
            flexibility in setting the aggregate thresholds, and the
            full scenario of procurement methods should be available.
